description.text: A phone dock for the OnePlus 2

Note: This model is currently quick work and untested.
Will updated once it has been tested.
  • Quick LED lamp for the incoming 2011 Hurricane Irene...
  • Insert LED's, Solder, GorillaPod it somewhere, And read through the hurricane.
  • Two attachment pads that -should be- compatible with GorillaPod tripods.
  • Back plate that shields electronics is held on by cantilever friction.

Setup: Insert 20 LEDs from lampshade side, bending each of the legs outwards to hold into the holes Leave enough gap to allow LEDs to be bent and re-pointed compensate for narrow beams. Soldering depends on your power source... 3 volts:
Each of the 4 rows should have 5 LEDs in parallel. connect the 4 rows in parallel.
Make sure to bend the LED legs the right way to make your life easier by aligning all. 12 Volts:
5 parallel rows of 4 LEDs in series My Current plan is to implement a pulse-width-modulation circuit using a micro-controller, using a voltage-control feedback, basically implementing switching. However, two 1.5v Alkaline batteries may accomplish the task as well, but will get dimmer with time (voltage falls off as battery is depleted.)

description.text: Yet another Rick's Portal Gun from Rick And Morty, which I have not even seen. This is not the most sophisticated build out there, but it's not too hard to print and assemble. A friend designed it in Tinkercad (his first model) and I made it makeable.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: Body: requires a printer with decent bridging support. There will be some droop in the muzzle, but it was minor and we decided it looked cool. There will be a lot of droop in the display cavity; I just cleaned it out with a hobby knife. The "bell" is in two pieces. I printed it in T-Glase (PET), but clear PLA would be nearly as transparent. I printed the cylinder with a single perimeter and no top or bottom. The settings on the top aren't too important; there will be some droop on the underside of the dome, but it doesn't show. Rescale the "ring" and reprint until it fits tightly around the bell cylinder.

Glue the two halves of the bell together with cyanoacrylate gel glue (superglue). Glue the ring onto the base carefully, right over the hole for the bell.
Lubricate the pin if you can - I used silicone grease. Snap the pin into the base, and the knob onto the pin. Insert the display into the base.
Optional easy whizziness: Tape a CR2302 coin cell battery onto a color-changing LED and tape the battery into the floor of the bell cavity.
Then push the bell onto the ring.

description.text:
I saw a toy desktop version of this on my boss' desk... so I decided I wanted to build one!
3D print 2 spindle halves, insert in 4 magnets and a thumb-tack (round low-profile type) & hot-glue the halves together. Print the base and drop in the magnets -- I didn't glue them in, but you could. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tXe8gBs1gYw Things you'll need -- 4 circular magnets & 4 rectangular magnets. RadioShack had these
Rectangular magnets dimensions: 0.862" x 1.87" x .0377" (Width,Length,Height)
Circular Magnets: 1.123" x 0.24" (Diameter, Thickness)
Thumb-tacks -- Check Walmart for these.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't Matter

20% or so...

Notes: Print support for the spindles. The support will fill in where the magnets sit.

Went to RadioShack and found some magnets that would work.
Went home and modeled the magnets and thumb tack. Once that was done I designed the spindle and base. I ensured that the magets on the base were slightly off center with lining up to the spindle such that the spindle would be forced up against the wall of the base. This toy worked on my first try!! Everyone at work really loves it too

title: Shakuhachi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: A precisely tuned highly playable shakuhachi (japanese end-blown bamboo-flute) with lowest tone in C. I uploaded one stl file of the entire flute, one file in which I cut the flute into 5 pieces and files of the individual pieces for separate printing. There is a joint between piece 2 and 3. It may require some polishing before it fits. To connect piece 1 and 2 as well as piece 3, 4 and 5, polish the end faces somewhat and use epoxy to glue them together. The mouthpiece may also require some gentle sharpening with polishing paper. If the low notes don't sound properly try polishing the inner wall with polishing paper wrapped around a stick, this helps.  It is modeled according to an original shakuhachi, it is highly playable, precise tuning and sounds great. I printed it in PLA with raft but no supports. Try glass or wood filled PLA for a better sound, but even standard PLA sounds good.

comments.text: 47 hours and 2 minutes. I beg you all who read this DO NOT PRINT THIS THING.
comments.author: tpayne22

comments.text: Whats your problem?? There are 5 seperate pieces. With a good printer and 30 percent infill each one takes about 4  to 5 hours to print. Yes 5 times 5 is 25 hours, but if you don't want a 3d printed shakuhachi just buy a real one. For 1000 US dollars you get a good one. I had no problems printing mine and it is perfectly tuned and sounds great. About your previous comment, just glue it together with epoxy, while aligning it with care. No need for joints, the are often not fitting that well and I found it is easier without. The point is that the joints must be absolutely airtight, and without glue this is difficult to achieve.
comments.author: tpayne22

comments.text: The fact that YOU expect me to buy epoxy, and use glue tells me that YOU are a lazy model maker.  This thing needs joints to be held together properly. Also, you are definitely not taking your time to listen to people in the comments telling you that your description is misleading.
comments.author: Caran

comments.text:
Karabas left this comment on my first shakuhachi model. On that day I sat down and immediately used his plan to create shakuhachi number 2 (this model), which has a non cylindrical bore modeled after his plans and published it for him the same day I received his comment. Thanks for blaming me to ignore comments. Maybe sometimes I do because I have a job to do and not the time to read the comments everyday, although I do at least once per week.
Yes, since you are an engineering student I appreciate that you like joints, and I hope your professor is proud of you that you paid so much attention in this class, but for a flute the pieces must fit absolutely airtight and after collecting quite some experience with bad joints in the past, I just found that simply using epoxy is doing the job much better without leaving air leaks. Sorry, this is my philosophy and if you don't like it don't print or add your own joints before printing.
I am sorry to hear that you cannot afford epoxy, but this I have very clearly written in the description, and I think I can expect from an engineering student that she is able to read the manual. Maybe try uploading your own design once so that you can appreciate the work of others. For your information, we the people who design and post things on Thingiverse are doing this for the joy of sharing their design and we are not receiving money for it. We do not owe you anything more than an accurate description, and my description is very detailed if you take your time to read it.

comments.text: Hi and thank you for taking the time to make all those shakuhachi files. I have one question about this: the description says it's in C, but is it pentatonic or diatonic?
comments.author: VinnyMask

comments.text:
Hi, this shakuhachi is pentatonic. I have also published a chinese version of a shakuhachi, the nanxiao which is diatonic:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1255820
The standard nanxiao has a notch instead of the sharp blow-edge of the shakuhachi, but I have uploaded 4 different headpieces with which you can transform it into either a traverse flute or a shakuhachi. Use the file nanxiao_shaku to replace the file nanxiao1 and you have a diatonic shakuhachi. A link to a fingering chart is in the description. The lowest tone is C and it is made to play either a C major or F major scale. However, since the tone is stabilized with some extra holes at the end it is more difficult to switch to the overtones. Chinese flutes feature a more full and stable sound with less overtones. It depends what you want. If you want to play traditional japanese shakuhachi music, it may be less suited. However, for western style music the naxiao features a very beautiful sound. Since you look for a diatonic shakuhachi you are probably more interested in the latter. Therefore, I encourage you to try it. I have copied it from my real nanxiao and it sounds as good as the original, although with a slightly different character.
comments.author: VinnyMask

comments.text: I printed entire shaku on big printer. It's about 30cm tall and extremly hard to play due to such small size. Why don't you model real sized shaku?
comments.author: Karabas

comments.text:
Hi Karabas,
my shakuhachi is real size, a bit more than 60 cm long. I apologize, the file for the entire shakuhachi was indeed a smaller version, while all the cut pieces were real size. I have to admit that I uploaded the wrong file. I have replaced the file by the correct larger version. It is quite playable and precisely tuned in full size, therefore I encourage you to give it another try if you have some plastic left.
In fact, the full size one was too long for the program I was using, therefore I designed it as the 30 cm version and then scaled it with Cura to the full size. The correct files are all marked with a "-big" at the end.
Caran

description.text:
This is a six sided die with a Pikachu face on three sides and a Pikachu tail on the other three. For use in the Pokemon trading card game whenever a heads or tails call is needed.
My son wanted to learn the Pokemon card game, so for his 7th birthday we went to the local game store for Pokemon league to learn how to play. We had the plastic coin used for all of the heads or tails calls needed in the game, but absolutely no one else was using a coin. They were all using a standard d6, evens were heads and odds were tails. This just would not do.

author: Rauglothgor

description.text:
I have recently built a ZMR250 Quad-Copter using a Sony CCD (PZ0420) board camera and felt that it was a little exposed at the front in event of a nose in crash.
So I designed a 'guard' which slips over the 2 front pilars and adds protection, without getting in the way of the view of the camera.
Simply print 2 of these, and mount them as shown in the photo.

Have you ever thought about how horrid it would be to loose 1 or more legs? How horrid it would be to never walk? Of course, you can buy prosthetic legs, but they are ridiculously expensive. This is where my leg comes in handy. This leg is designed to be cheap, so you can print it from your own printer. Once you have printed the 2 part foot, one for each leg, it is very easy to assemble. An interlocking joint between the leg and the foot allows a quick and easy snap-fit. This joint also allows you to move the foot in 360 degree angles, something even a normal foot cannot do. When the foot is in impact with the ground, the joint will automatically adjust itself, making the foot go down, just like the foot of a human. The rugged sole of the foot also provides easy walking or running on all terrain. The size for this leg is a one size fits all. You just put what is left of your leg inside the hole and then take a long thick piece of filament and string it through the holes on the outside and then tie it like a shoe. If you need to adjust the height, you can do so on the printing app. So download this leg, and be able to enjoy the happiness of walking, and smile, that technology enhanced your life.

author: yenlo

description.text:
The piece replaces the handle of my camera tripod that got broken. So I made a new one.
It's actually the first object i design and print. And it worked out very well.
i designed it with Sketchup
If you have a rechargeable LED light that plugs into a US wall socket, this will clip it to a ring inside a tent or some other place that needs light.

Print away. My copy got bitten by the skeinforge no-infill bug, so to make it strong enough I filled the space between the insider and outside ring with glue. Someone smarter will make the infill happen properly. Also, if you want a solid ring that you can just clip a carabiner to, delete the tiny little angled block.
And the module for carving out the plug holes has a parameter for tightness of fit. You can adjust this for your machine.
Finally, please don't make derivatives intended to incorporate conductors.

author: gerald2015

title: Y-Axis Bracket for Mini 3D Fabrikator Tiny Boy Final Highly Recommended

description.text: I had seriously reviewed a few of the designs for the Y-Axis Stepper Motor Fan Mount portion and concluded the best position for the most limited space constrained part on the Mini Fabrikator TinyBoy. Never design something that will block or hit the movement of the print while it is moving or that you're zeroing at full bed length tests! It is very obvious on larger size prints near 80mm. Heat without bracket has reached 56 to 60deg Celsius for stock printer. If your stepper reached 80deg Celsius, it would mean your POTs on Ramps Board for all steppers are not normally set to 0.60-0.62V and 1.12 at the other measured legs. Below these volts and you'll notice the extrude pauses for half a sec at certain prints resulting in multiple stains. The bracket is capable of reducing between 7 to 10deg Celsius differences as tested. Prior to the big 12cm strong fan bringing down X & Z Axis to near 34deg Celsius, putting the tiny bracket for my 30mm fan has successfully maintained the temperature to around 49deg Celsius during operation. The printer has been printing non-stop 24hours for weeks to near months without problems. I had chosen ABS Black material base (Black absorbs heat in my view) on the heat produced from the Y-Stepper but you can opt for PLA in your preferences. ABS does warp without hotbed but in my case, since it is tiny and small, I regard it negligible and acceptable as a functional excellent solution. For any equipment, as long as the operating temperature is maintained at minimal, it will be prolonged for it's lifespan. If you like the design and you would like to donate as an appreciation, you can paypal any amount to [email protected] for supporting my continual research test materials. Hope you all like it!

title: Morning On The Farm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Few things in life are as simple as an early morning on the farm, as demonstrated in this scene lasercut from foamcore. This piece is one of several vignette designed around Inventor Studio's Lasercut Foamcore Scenes, a simple interlocking geometry system for foamcore. Like this scene, but want it include pigs? Maybe what's missing is corn growing in the fields of the background. Design additional elements yourself using the included interlocking base shape and make this scene your own. Teachers might consider using this interlocking system in makerspaces and other project-based classroom learning environments. Other designs released so far in this series can be found here and here. Hurry now and finish your chores. Breakfast will be on soon.

Lasercutting & Assembly Instructions An SVG file has been included for each layer of this design, together with a layered Inkscape SVG file containing all the elements. Cutting the pieces on your laser should be very straightforward if you've cut and engraved foamcore before. Multi-pass cuts using reduced power are recommended, because this reduces the amount of foam shrinkage. The cost of colored foamcore is often much higher than plain white. Sometimes a scene element calls for an unavailable color. Some elements may be best rendered using more than a single color plus the white that's revealed through the engraving process. The piece of foamcore used for the rooster in this scene was marked up using a Sharpie before being engraved and cut. My daughter Mei-Mei insisted on coloring the cow's udders as the scene was being assembled. Some layers in this design involve gluing different colored pieces onto the base part. Look carefully at the photo, paying attention to whether the additional pieces are glued in front or in back of the base piece. Inexpensive bailing wire and painters tape are used to attach hanging elements of the scene.

Designed Using Inkscape This Inventor Studios' Lasercut Foamcore Scene was designed using Inkscape. You can edit the Inkscape SVG files found in this Thing to make modifications to this scene or create wholly new scenes for yourself, for classroom instruction, and to share with others.

Hi,
Here are some preliminary results of experiments on an Helios 44-2 to make it soft focus-monocle lens.
My first try was to remove every lens but the front one. This works fine but gives quite a tele lens.
I then tried to keep the front lens and also the rear element which is acting as a focal reducer. (only the rear lens of the front element is then removed)
The drawback with this configuration is that there is no way to focus to infinity with the standard M42 adapter which is too long by around 5mm.
To fix this, I 3D printed a dedicated M39 to M42 adapter that I screw on my NEX-M39 adapter. I must admit it becomes a very tricky lens. Somewhat difficult to find a correct focus when wide open. But, just close it between 2.8 and 4.0 and you get something quite fun: a mixture between radial unfocusing and swirly bokeh﻿. I use it on a SONY-a6000 mirrorless camera.
Take care when using this lens on a DSLR, the rear of the lens might come in contact with the mirror...

Hi there.
I just bought this lens to pair with my A6000. I used slim adapter m42-nex yet not even once I can get the focus and clear picture. left alone the swirly bokeh.
So, what did I missing here?should I buy the normal dumb adapter such as Fotga?or the lens that I bought was faulty one.
Thanks.
btw, your picture truly awesome
comments.author: futahas

comments.text:
Hi Futahas,
It is quite difficult to get a swirly image on a crop sensor with an helios 44. The swirly effect comes from vigneting and some aberrations which are more pronounced at the edge of the lens. A crop sensor (like on A6000) does not use the whole image given by the lens...
To maximize chances to get a swirly image you must leave the diaphragm wide open, focus on an object not far from the lens (2 meters or so) and put in your composition a back ground let's say 2 meters away from your subject...

Those clips that clip onto DIP chips are very convenient for debugging and logic analyzing.  Unfortunately, they are really expensive for the hobbyist, especially when you need to buy so many different sizes.
SO....make your own.
Sorry, I did not use SCAD, so I can't offer a customizer compatible version.  I did make all the usual sizes for DIP chips, but if you need me to make more, let me know.
Revision June 22, 2016: I removed the little dividers on the top and reworked the model for a clean mesh.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

as high as you can!

Notes: Print two of these to make one clip! These need to be printed cleanly with maximum detail -- no warping or stringing. Use a small nozzle (0.4mm or less) and thin layers (0.15mm or less). Use a strong plastic without too much flex. ABS or PLA probably better than nylon here. You shouldn't need supports. Brim or raft may be useful if you experience warping or the part pulls off the bed.

After printing and cleaning the print.... Push a 2mm rod or long finish nail through the hinges to join the two clip halves. It should be a tight fit, but drill out if necessary. Install a spring (or two) in the circular spots on the insides of the clip. Make sure you can still open the clip wide enough to get around a chip. After 2mm rod and spring.... Slide in pins. I used gold plated 21 gauge brass 2" Head Pins: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006Q2YZ52 Push them into so they extend out the bottom and top. Secure with glue if needed. Or heat the pin with a torch and let it melt its way through. the pins bend easily -- use the straight ones! Trim the bottom of the pins so they are flush with the bottom edge of the clip. The tips of the pins "float" a little bit in the gaps -- this lets them flex when the push against the chip leads. Trim the tops of the pins to the desired length. You might want to keep the pin heads as they help grabbers stay in place....(as long as they do not short pins) Attach your test leads and clamp it onto a chip!

comments.text: The print is pretty challenging for 2.54mm pitch chips, so you would have to take some real care and patience to get 1.27mm pitch version usable.  The main tricky spot is the thin walls between the wires that reach between the leads to grab the chip body. A very small nozzle, 0.25mm or smaller, very clean printing filament, and a slicer that supports single walls would likely be required.

description.text: I came up with an idea for this this modular wheelchair arm. I can spin and pivot, and has been designed in such a way you can attach different holders to the end depending on what you want to hold in it.

I read a bit about the daily problems of a wheelchair user and one of the things that stuck out was that bathroom mirrors are always just a little too high up to see and use effectively. My initial though was that if you have a smartphone you can just the front face camera to check yourself out, but then the problem is that you only have one free hand if you want to fix your hair or put on make up. With that in mind I though an arm to connect on to the side of the wheelchair could be really handy, and probably has a lot of use outside this context as well.

I wanted the entire thing to be made of 3D printed components and no external hardware or tools needed. I also wanted it to be easily suited to any particular users needs, so everything in the project uses the same sized threads/bolts (which are also printed). Because of this, you can add extra shafts and connectors wherever you need them, making the arm as long/short/flexible as you need it.
I used OpenSCAD to design the parts, the code from which is included in the project files (though fair warning, it's not the nicest code in the world!).
For this project I used PLA, but it would work much better in ABS.

I used/modified two amazing parts in this project: 1) mike_linus's NUT JOB thread library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647)
2) emmet's geared bearing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

80% for nuts/threaded rod, 20%-50% for everything else

Notes: I intentionally designed everything to be printable without supports. Some parts (like the clip fastener) are better printed on the side for strength, but the threading can be negatively effected if the printer is a little out of calibration.

The first iteration used ball and socket joints, which worked pretty good and had a really nice range of movement, but the printing of such parts is more hassle, and I wanted this to be as easy as possible to print out and use.
Instead I went for a hinging joint, which has more limited range of movement but is compensated by the fact that the entire arm can rotate around on the bearing built into the base.

title: Glue Dust Tray for Zortrax M200

description.text: Elmer's glue stick, along with the Zortrax perfboard and raft, provides excellent print adhesion for all materials. My printer, however tends to accumulate unsightly dried glue dust from scraping the bed between prints, so I designed this slide-on tray into which the dust can be swept, keeping the printer clean. It slides easily onto the older v1 perfboard; users of the v2 may have to enlarge the slots a bit. If printed in PLA (as I've done) it's probably a good idea to remove the tray when using the bed heater, but if you're printing with ABS you should probably remove the bed anyway for print removal due to the force required. PLA prints, requiring no bed heat, can be popped off with minimal force without removing the bed. The design can be edited on Tinkercad at https://tinkercad.com/things/evclLyuzWxC

My second attempt at creating a simple, mechanical, weight-driven clock with the fewest parts. It uses 4mm brass shafts, a 1# drive weight, and currently, two ballpoint pens as the winding weight. The pendulum is a 1/4" aluminum tube, and I mounted it to a mirror. It works, but it needs improvement.
Specifically:
hands
a ratcheting winding system
a crutch system so that the pendulum does not have to swing as much
a clock face
a neater way to attach the weights The gear train and escapement are pretty universal so that it may be rearranged (see the not overly accurate previous version in red). This also allows all parts to function with minimal post-print finishing. Note: Gear tooth size and shaft holes are all very slightly offset inward to compensate for my printer's tendency to over-extrude. UPDATE: As requested, I posted the additional parts needed to make the red (column) version of the clock (minus the holders for the quarters at the ends of the seesaw pendulum which I cannot find). To make this version, you'll need anything without "v2" in the file name plus wheel4v2. Even so, the pendulum needs to be adjusted to keep accurate time. UPDATE 2: Added renders of the different gear configurations. UPDATE 3:
Assembly instructions:
-Ensure gear teeth are free of artifacts and that all will rotate easily on their shafts.
-Glue ONE of the mount pieces to whatever you are using as a backing (in my case, the mirror).
-Slot 4mm shafts into their mounts (you'll have to figure out the length).
-Take about 2m of cord and wrap it around the drum on wheel 4 (it took me three wraps of the necklace cord I used to develop sufficient friction with the weights I used).
-Onto the shaft in the shorter mount (the one connected to the pendulum pivot) slide the escape wheel, minute wheel (3), and hour wheel (5).
-On the taller mount slot the 60 tooth gear (2) and the wheel with the drum (4).
-With painstakingly minuscule adjustments, slide the unglued mount around until you find the sweet spot where the gears mesh with the least resistance.
-Glue the free mount in place on the backing once you are satisfied or out of patience.
-Slide the arch-shaped frame piece on to the shaft with wheels two and four and glue the other frame pieces to the arch and the backing material using a similar process as described in the preceding two steps.
-Attach a pendulum to the anchor (using a simple pendulum close to 1m in length will yield the required two second period. Keep it light weight regardless and be prepared to spend time adjusting it)
-Tie the drive weight on the left side and the winding weight on the right side.
-Mount it to the wall
-Watch it tick
-Design and print some hands and otherwise modify it to your heart's content. FYSA:
-However you mount the clock to the wall, ensure the pendulum is balanced so that the anchor achieves the same amount of lock in each direction.
-Since the main shaft is cantilevered, ensure the mount is robust enough to prevent it from getting pushed sideways from sustained torque from the weight. PLA to mirror is not robust enough without the right glue.
-This was a very early escapement design, so unless the pendulum swings sufficiently, it behaves more like a recoil escapement than a Graham escapement. I might improve it eventually. UPDATE 4:
I added a new escape wheel and anchor that should be more efficient as mentioned in the previous update. They are untested as I do not currently have printer access, but they worked well in a computer simulation.
Also user Zarlor made these excellent assembly animations for both configurations which are probably easier to follow than my posted instructions.
http://gph.is/2alyFDR
http://gph.is/2aYdpDL UPDATE 4.1 I re-uploaded the new anchor with slightly trimmed pallets and slightly less drop. This should prevent you from have to trim them by hand or sand down the back side of the escape teeth. Again, this is an untested modification. UPDATE 5: I added a two piece mount and frame. Using these parts should eliminate all of the tedious wiggling and adjusting as described above during assembly. The caveat is that your printer must be very accurate (unlike my old printer on which I first printed this design) to ensure the gears mesh properly. Also, the frame will resist the flexural stress from the clock weight with the part's z-axis which is the weakest dimension. Be careful of adding too much weight (especially if you use a pulley).

title: Party Popper Gun
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Before anyone asks "Why?", my answer is this: "Just because, okay, get off my back" Party poppers are fun, but making a firing mechanism just makes them more fun. I may make a six-shooter version next. To load this device:

  • take a standard party popper (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_popper), and insert it into the barrel, thin end first. Push the Hammer all the way forward (while pulling the trigger slightly), then release the trigger so that the latch catches the hammer.

  • push the party popper all the way into the barrel, so that the thin end protrudes, then push it back about 1cm (the gun needs a little wind up to get momentum to pull the string).

  • loosen the string, then wrap it around the hammer, pulling it snugly through the notch to secure.

  • pull the trigger to fire.

• Print all parts ( "platedgun_fixed.stl" contains all parts):
    -6 x dowels
    -4 x spacers
    -1 x fat spring retainer
    -1 x gun body
    -1 x trigger
    -1 x hammer
    -1 x handle OR 1 x handle-RIGHT & 1 x handle-LEFT

  • sand/grind the parts as required to make the printed dowels fit into the holes provided

  • insert the dowels into one side of the handle (as shown in the pictures).

  • install the spacer rings, hammer, trigger, barrel, and spring retainer.

  • Insert a spring (8mm OD * 20mm long) between the spring retainer and the hammer.

  • it helps if you use some glue to stick the end of the spring into the spring retainer.

  • press fit the other side of the handle. ready for fun!
    • EDIT: I have uploaded a slightly stronger design for the HAMMER component, as mine failed. I suggest printing this part at 80% infil with 4 perimeters and solid infil every 4 layers, to get a slightly stronger part.

title: Flexible Foot for QU-BD One/Two-Up Dampening Feet/Struts

description.text: I've been using the dampening struts from DDeGonge888 since I first received my Qu-Bd Two-Up over a year ago and have been supremely satisfied with their performance. Recently, I began tinkering with flexible filaments and thought, "How cool would it be to have rubber feet on these?". So, I took his design and drew up a set of feet that can be printed in Ninjaflex (or your favorite rubbery filament) and will fit just right. NOTE: these are designed to fit V1 of the struts, not the newer V2.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes: I personally used the settings above, however, I've found on my machine that using infill with Ninjaflex just doesn't work out very well. (As I'm sure you can tell by my pictures.) Be that as it may, they are perfectly usable the way they are and I was too lazy to reprint them. ;-) Knowing what I know now, I think I'd use about 50% to get a little firmer support. ALSO if your machine is like mine and the dimensions of your parts are fudged just a little (For me, stuff is usually a hair tighter than expected because of the slight ridges from the layers.) you may want to scale the foot up slightly. If your prints come out perfectly, use the files as-is. If not, I scaled mine up to 1.02x and they fit perfectly.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9vPzIk8T5BW

I really liked birdhouse X, but it had a fatal flaw: the entrance hole was way too big (IMHO). So I reduced the size of it, it's now 25x40mm, which look much more in the ballpark from what I could gather online.
The other addition that I made is that I thought it looked like a German Cuckoo clock (the ones with a bird that comes out every hour). To keep it simple I changed the clock to a sundial, with the gnomon serving as perch for the birds.

Cut it out of 3mm (ply)wood with your lasercutter of choice. The drawings are laid out for 2 birdhouses as that would fit exactly on our 600x300mm laser and wood. The sundial part is copied from an English version, which means that it is set up for a latitude of 51 deg North. It should work OK for my country, but your milage may vary if you are in a substantially different latitude. On the other hand: who cares really? There are better ways to tell time anyway.

A nice simple 22degree camera mount, takes FatShark Pilot cams, HS1177 and PZ cameras in their cases, uses a O'ring to hold it in place and recommend a small piece of double sided tape for dampening. Due to the coarseness of the 3d printed surface the ring won't slide, plus because of its structure wrapped in such a way it locks it's self in quiet nicely... special thanks to my buddy Jeff, for the idea of the o-ring. After many successes with the design it would still pop off the frames with only double sided tape holding the assembly down, hence the redesign and addition of the 3mm bolt and slot for a 3mm Nylock nut. nice and clean, very elegant and functional.

title: Headphone Adapter for Behind-the-Ear Hearing Aids
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
See update section at bottom for changes!
Customizer is now finished! This build is now compatable with all BTE Hearing Aids 
This (originally was) an adapter to connect a Phonak Bolero V BTE Hearing Aid to Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth headset.
Story:
Over the last few years, I had always felt that I was developing hearing loss in my one ear. It was not until this past summer that I learn the truth.
I finally convinced by mother to get me hearing test, and I was exactly right—my left ear has had severe hearing loss since birth, and I would need a hearing aid in that ear to compensate. After three months, I finally had a personal hearing aid.
They say that necessity is the mother of invention, and in this case, that was completely true. I like to listen to music, but I realized that Behind-the-Ear (BTE) Hearing Aids have a custom ear-mold over the ear's opening, and that the microphone, well, is behind the ear. This would mean that any set headphones would not be able to be used unless the unit was taken off. As I am prone to forgetting things (I also have ADD), I knew it would not work. So after multiple iterations of designs (Version 3 can be seen in the background of the cover photo), I finally arrived at this design.
The Next Step:
I am hoping to create a MakerBot Customizer so that all hearing aids and headphones will be supported.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.010 in

Infill:

Full

Notes: This was printed on a uPrint SE Plus at my high school. (I do not own a printer.) This used a separate support material that had to be dissolved in a acid bath.
Support Material Removal Removing support material is required after printing.
This was originally designed in Autodesk Inventor Professional 2014 on a Educational License. The parametric version was made in openscad
Customizer is finished! Version 3 and 4 are now outdated and are kept for legacy purposes.

description.text:
I made these this year as a thank you gift for our Haunted House cast and crew.
It Uses the standard Cube Gear SCAD setup and the nice parametric pins. Assembly is a bit tricky, knowing which piece fits where. I'll try to upload some updates to it this month that will help.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: As with most gear art.. there's plenty of flat surface to stick down, so I leave it to your own choice how you print it.. but I did these without any raft or support.
Using the great cube gear SCAD model setup from user: http://www.thingiverse.com/emmett/about I melded that with a pumpkin model in SCAD and let it do its magic.

Hi, yes, you need to print one of each piece.. except the bottom which I supplied a version with and without the logo.
Each one is different because the pumpkin is a unique shape all the way around.
-redpawfx

comments.text: Thanks for making this, my kids love these geared things!
comments.author: Oggelboggel

comments.text: Hi. I'm struggling with the assembly :) Could you post some instructions please?
comments.author: ivancentes

comments.text:
Hi, I wanted to add number cutouts to the interior pieces but I just never had time. The best way I have found to assemble the piece is to start from the bottom and work your way up. put on the bottom piece first and then look at it from the bottom and use the ridges and troughs to figure out which of the 3 small gears lines up where. there's only really one location for each since they're tapered and when you have it right, the surface will be smooth across the gear mesh and you can run your fingers down the crease and feel how well they line up , same for the big pieces, if you look at them from a cross section side view you can see the profile of the pumpkin shape, and also of note is that the big pieces have a "flat top" when looking at them in the "up" direction they are printed on. so thats up and the part that should mesh with the "stem" piece..
-redpawfx

author: sourabhsethi8888

description.text:
Noah's Ark as transcribed into 8 tactile pictures, including a key. Available Models
  • Frame-Only
  • Binder Holes on Top
  • Binder Holes on Left
    • Available Versions
  • Key
  • Page 1: "Building the Ark"
  • Page 2 : "Gathering Food"
  • Page 3: "Animals Came in Pairs"
  • Page 4: "It Began to Rain and Flood"
  • Page 5: "Ark on a Mountain"
  • Page 6: "Dove with an Olive Leaf"
  • Page 7: "Rainbow Over Ark"
    • Visually impaired children who are in the process of constructing an understanding of their world often learn through guided tactile stimulation and instruction using various means, including tactile pictures. The lack of easily reproducible and customizable tactile pictures in the visually impaired community imposes an educational challenge wherein teachers of the visually impaired (TVIs) must use labor-intensive, time-consuming means to construct meaningful tactile experiences for their students. These designs hope to take advantage of 3D printing technology to create easily printable and customizable tactile pictures. Feel free to modify & customize!

Overview All models were designed on CraftML, an XML-style markup language for 3D modeling that includes support for Braille text. Tactile Picture Book Project
Further information regarding the effort to transcribe picture books into an accessible tactile format. Designing Noah's Ark in 3D
Post detailing my in-depth design process on 3DA11y, a blog dedicated to sharing information about opportunities in 3D accessibility.

Changes as of 11/27/2015 Updated pages now feature
  • rounded frames
  • longer captions
  • more space between items on page
    • Specific changes made to the pages include
  • Page 4: wave texture now facing reader (instead of side view)
  • Page 6: filled in hole on dove
  • Page 7: rainbow no longer stretched out

title: Pop Can Opener | Designed for People with Prosthetics or Severe Arthritis

description.text: This is a pop can opener… more specifically though it’s an incredibly simple, easy to print, and inexpensive lever extension for opening up pop cans with ease. simply slip the lever into place on the tab of a pop can and pull the lever back. Voilà the pop can is open with barely any force required!

This project started out as a gift for my mother and was a complete success. It has a long way to go, though. While this pop can opener works great and doesn't need a whole lot more tweaking, it's only the beginning. I want this design to inspire new similar designs with a focus on simplicity, inexpensiveness, and ease of use. There's no moving parts, no unnecessary fanciness (although early versions of the design had both of these), it's a simple solution that just works. I plan on continuing to come up with similar designs and I hope everyone who sees this can be inspired to pursue a similar line of thought when coming up with tools for those with arthritis/prosthetics.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

As high as you can manage

Infill:

The arm needs to be strong so use a high infill.

Notes: When printing this design, it's important to consider how FDM printing works and how the layers affect the strength of the part. The can opener's arm has to go through a decent amount of strain when it's being used so the print layers need to be oriented to maximize its strength. if you print the part vertically you'll get stacked layers on the arm that won't be able to withstand the sheer forces for very long. It's much better to print horizontally so the layers are parallel with the length/direction of the arm.

As I mentioned above, this pop can opener was originally designed as a gift idea for my mother. My mom has Lymes disease which causes her to have a substantial amount of arthritis like pain in her hands. I wanted to design and print her something that would help her regain a little bit of independence, even if that independence is as simple as being able to open a pop can without help from others. Needless to say, she was very excited to receive the gift.
It was shortly after that, that I realized the pop can opener had an even bigger potential as a tool for individuals with prosthetics. It's about getting your freedom back. Doing so doesn't have to be complicated, and it definitely shouldn’t have to be expensive. That’s the line of thought that I'm trying to inspire in myself and others with this design. Yes it's "just" a pop can opener, it's not necessarily going to revolutionize much. However maintaining/inspiring this perspective of efficient, inexpensive, simple solutions for those who deserve independence in their everyday lives… that could make a big difference.

This is a new X endstop that mounts on the left side to the X-axis rails. It is designed to contact the X-axis extruder carriage. I started with this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037870 and added a higher mount so that it works with the Folger Tech 2020 Prusa i3.

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

10%

comments.text: Since this only works on the left and the new build guide instructs you to put the endstop on the right, I've posted a remix here. Thanks to you and the maker of the original for doing the hardest part.
comments.author: NinthDimension

comments.text: This fit my printer great; finally a nice x-endstop.
comments.author: georgefrick

comments.text: This is way better than the kind of crappy design by folgertech, thank you!
comments.author: Mindforrest

comments.text: I like your design because it get's rid of an issue I am having with the smooth rods rotating in the brackets, thus causing the end stop to rotate around when the z-axis goes up and tension is put on its cable. I do have one concern with this design though. Is it possible that this end stop mount will slide along the smooth rods? The original mounts were able to be tightened so that they would not slide when the printer head came into contact with it.
comments.author: PteroDancer

comments.text: Thank you for your comment. I designed this part for the same reasons that you described, and I also had the same concerns with whether it would move on its own.  However, the part snaps firmly onto the smooth rods, and it takes quite a bit of force to move it. My rails have even been greased to make them more slick, but still no problems. Give it a try, I hope it works for you.
comments.author: PteroDancer

comments.text: Turns out I can't just mirror the end stop and use it on the right side of the printer head (I wasn't thinking), I ended up dremeling the piece to get the recessed areas in the right spot to accommodate solder joints so it would sit flush. All is well now, thank you.

description.text:
This is a charging stand for Pebble Time / Time Steel. 
To install the charging connector push it in at an angle cable-relief end first. Once it's in its channel snap in the main part of the connector into place.
It can be mirrored and should work just as well if you prefer the "leg" to be on the other side.
(Printed at 0.1mm with Printrbot Simple Metal)

comments.author: jrdmellow

comments.text:
Hi, I printed this at 0.1mm 20% on my Mendel (Reprap) and it looks great (for a self-assembled cheap chinese printer, I mean).
The upper side of the connector window snapped off while pushing the connector, and the cable doesn't fit very well inside the pillar. I think maybe due to some shrinkage of my ABS while cooling down. Perhaps this should be printed at 101% in size (don't know if this is possible with Cura or Pronterface).
Anyway, my Time fits and connects nicely and I'm happy with my charging stand, just hoping for a (faster) (more precise) new printer!
comments.author: ivanxx

comments.text: I just printed one on a Form 2 printer. The charger fits like a glove but it doesn't quite make contact with the charging points. I put my watch on the stand and the magnets connect but I have to squeeze it together for the pins on the charger cable to make contact with the watch.
comments.author: Spider_Tech

comments.text: Yes, the model was designed with FDM printers in mind so there are some very thin walls in the charger opening that are supposed to be rounded off by the FDM process limitations (If I remember correctly Fusion360 had some problems removing them at the time so I left them in knowing that a slicer will round them off). With higher res SLA printer it is possible that the opening will be too small to make contact and that you will have to trim the slot a little bit :)
comments.author: Spider_Tech

comments.text: Please note that the cable for the Pebble Time Steel is a bit thicker and it doesn't fit in this design.
comments.author: Shyish

comments.text: No it's not. You can clearly see Pebble Time Steel as well as it's included cable on my photos and on few of the 'makes' for this thing. It is possible that Pebble changed the design of the cable but I'm not aware of it. I would verify if your printer isn't over-extruding.
comments.author: Shyish

comments.text: Had to midtfjords it a bit with a knife otherwise great design!!

comments.text: Great design! Mine printed wonderfully, unfortunately the plastic on the top right of the charge connector snapped as I was inserting the actual cable. Still, it looks and functions great. A little superglue will fix it right up. Thanks!

description.text:
This single model printed in multiple copies allows to create a picture gallery in which you can change pictures easily if needed.
You just need to nail the frames to drywall using small nails. Frames should be spaced  so that pictures can slide in without falling out. Both horizontal and vertical orientations can be done using the same part. The same piece has groves on both sides, allowing to use hold 2 pictures.
It takes about 15 minute to print each piece. I had to turn model 45 degrees in order to fit it on the printing bed.
Scaling is appropriate if you need bigger or smaller format.
This is just a 15 mm cube test.

author: Laurycamargob

title: Hearing Aid case for Kirkland Signature 5

description.text: Hearing Aid case for Kirkland Signature 5 Premium Hearing Aids, (which are the same size and shape as some other hearing aids) This is a tough little case that can protect the hearing aids from a lot of abuse. I was aiming for maximum protection with minimum size plus 2 sets of batteries.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm layer or better

Infill:

solid

Notes: Print: 1 main body; 2 lids; 2 battery holders; 1 set of supports, if needed The lids and battery holders are ABS; the main body is Taulman 3D PCTPE.
I printed the 2 support pieces first, (I used ABS - anything will do) then removed them from the print-bed, and made sure they were clean and smooth. Next I put blue tape on the top surface of both support parts. Finally, while the main body was printing, I paused the print just before the overhang layer around the outside and placed the support ring over the print, tape side up; I repeated this for the central bridged area.
I did it this way because I wanted very smooth areas for the lids and hearing aids to sit/set on/in with as little clean-up as possible and this seemed like the best way for the printers I have.
Before use, I added small, soft, fuzzy bits of fleece to the lids and main body of the case where the hearing aids would touch, using double sided tape dots, to keep aids cushioned and safe.
I started by scanning the hearing aids on my flatbed scanner and then importing the scan into SketchUp to give me the outline of the inside of the case spaces.

title: Shot On Goal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Triumph and anguish are both captured in this soccer scene lasercut from foamcore. This piece is one of several vignette designed around Inventor Studio's Lasercut Foamcore Scenes, a simple interlocking geometry system for foamcore. Like this scene, but want tit include pigs? Maybe what's missing is corn growing in the fields of the background. Design additional elements yourself using the included interlocking base shape and make this scene your own. Teachers might consider using this interlocking system in makerspaces and other project-based classroom learning environments. Other designs released so far in this series can be found here, here, and here. Goal!

Lasercutting & Assembly Instructions An SVG file has been included for each layer of this design, together with an Inkscape SVG file containing all the elements. Cutting the pieces on your laser should be very straightforward if you've cut and engraved foamcore before. Multi-pass cuts using reduced power are recommended, because this reduces the amount of foam shrinkage. Inexpensive bailing wire and painters tape are used to attach hanging elements of the scene.

Designed Using Inkscape This Inventor Studios' Lasercut Foamcore Scene was designed using Inkscape. You can edit the Inkscape SVG files found in this Thing to make modifications to this scene or create wholly new scenes for yourself, for classroom instruction, and to share with others.

This is a 3D-printable dust cap for a Celestron 5SE (5" / 127 mm diameter) Schmidt-Cassegrain Telescope. (I bought my telescope second-hand, and the original owner had lost the dust cap for the main objective.) There are 6 little tapered "nubs" on the outside diameter which give a good secure press-fit into the end of the telescope. You can easily adapt the design to suit telescopes with larger or smaller apertures by scaling the STL to suit - just check the clear inside diameter of the surround of your telescope's .objective, and scale the STL to ensure the "nubs" are just sightly larger diameter - the tapers should allow it to wedge in securely. Alternatively, the original parametric CAD model is "Shared" publicly in my OnSpace account - search https://www.onshape.com/ for "Celestron 5SE Dust Cap".

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes: Mine is printed in PLA, but ABS may be a better choice, if your printer is up for it. Note that this creates a large, thin, flat part, so you need to have your first layer well sorted, and you need to be able to print without warping / edge lift. Support not required, but printing with a "Brim" may help the model to stick down without lifting.

The original parametric CAD model is "Shared" publicly in my OnSpace account - search https://www.onshape.com/ for "Celestron 5SE Dust Cap", and then you can tweak all of the dimensions to suit your telescope.

author: ashtreeliu

description.text: the last one is the I-rex

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

V1 is designed to cut 223/5.56 brass so it can be formed into 300 blackout.  It cuts the brass to 1.39"-1.40" on a 2" mini chop saw.
V2 needs no support, has a plunger to push the brass off the fixture after it is cut and it shortened the cut length to 1.37"-1.38" for less trimming.  
V3 is further refined jig thanks to ummmbilly's make inspiring improvement.  The plunger uses two AR15 magazine catch springs and has a cap that threads into the shaft to keep the springs enclosed. 
The brass clamp is the same for all fixtures.  The locating pin is the same on both the V2 and V3.  The other parts are fixture specific.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: All jigs require an AR-15 Buffer Retainer Spring to work for the brass clamp. (.19" dia x .92" long) V3 is designed to use two AR15 magazine catch springs on the plunger rod and one m3 SHCS to hold the plunger cap on the rod. Remove the factory vise from the chop saw and place the fixture's locating boss into the hole in the saw's base. Place the thumbscrew through the fixture and thread it with the nut in the saw base's bottom groove. Align it square with your eyes. Place the clamp in the slot clearance pocket and slide it forward within the rails. When installing the clamp in the fixture, orient the dovetail so it will be touching the brass. Place the spring in the pocket and you are ready to trim brass.

author: Laurycamargob

description.text: A small desk organizer for small things.

This device was designed for the assistive tech challenge. It is a remote medical alarm that will allow a person to alert those near by to an emergency. It can be placed with double adhesive tape on the out side of an apartment door, given to your next door neighbor or care taker. I have two methods of triggering the alarm. The first method is via the remote clicker for conscious assistance and the other is with micro controller that can monitor vitals like heart rate (similar to the setup found here> http://forum.arduino.cc/index.php?topic=71386.0 <). This is not a new concept but having access to this without having to spend hundreds or thousands of dollars make it feasible for more people. And possibly save someones life. I must say though THIS IS NOT MEANT TO REPLACE CERTIFIED MEDICAL EQUIPMENT. I don't take any responsibility for the use or failure of this device. My friends room mate with a heart condition passed away because she didn't have access to something like this. So having this could have saved her life.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: The stl files are generated at 1/10th scale by Inventor so they need to be resized at a 10 to 1 ratio to print as intended. The printing is pretty straight forward, all parts are designed to print with the flattest side facing down. Unless you know how to prevent warping it is best to print out of PLA. Just in case it isn't clear. The red cross should be printed with a transparent filament. You can color it with a red sharpie if you need to.

Remote relay can be found here: http://www.amazon.com/Channel-Wireless-Learning-Control-Transmitter/dp/B00XY60SP4/ref=sr_1_fkmr3_2?s=photo&ie;=UTF8&qid;=1446421833&sr;=8-2-fkmr3&keywords;=latching+relay+remote+rf+12v Battery pack can be found here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/Mini-Portable-DC-168-12V-Rechargeable-Li-ion-Battery-Pack-for-CCTV-Camera-OK-/272016950890?hash=item3f5579466a:g:PYcAAOSwI-BWH1Uu The light and siren are from this: http://www.ebay.com/itm/For-US-Mini-12V-Strobe-Flashing-Light-Lamp-Siren-Home-Security-Wired-Sound-Alarm-/381452701060?hash=item58d05a4d84:g:rlMAAOSwm8VUyDgr

The 3d printed parts are the housing to mount the following components. I currently don't have the parts but they are connected as follows. ( I would hope that the entry is judged for the intended purpose and not docked because I can't afford to purchase the components right now.) First take the battery pack and strip back the wire to the male connector and tin them with a soldering iron.
Next take the light and siren out of the flasher and wire it up to the output on the relay module.
Next take the stripped end of the battery connector and connect the proper polarity of wire to the power input on the relay module.
Now take the clear red cross ( you can print it in clear then color the inside red with sharpie) and glue it where it rests snugly to the out side of the case.
Then take all the electronics and hot glue them in place. (the switch on the battery fits in the rectangle on the bottom and the female end can fit in the circle cut out on the side.)
make sure the light is in the red cross.
Follow the instructions with the relay to make sure the button is set to one click on one click off.
Test it then if everything works screw or glue the back on and place it where every or with who every you can trust will help.

description.text: Holder for blower used into my Prusa i3 A620

Update 08/18/16 -
Remodeled both the ring and the base plate. I wanted a design that required minimal supports to print. I also wanted to add the some minor changes to help with overall use. There is now a screw/bolt location that aligns the two pieces. And hopefully the ease of overhangs helps with faster printing. Update 08/11/16 -
Added a JPG graphic that is a template for light reflector's and a diffuser to go behind the emblem. In my original prototype I used glossy photo paper to make the reflectors. I cut out the shapes and then super glued them to the base plate. For the diffuser I cut two piece of clear acetate then sandwich a piece of tissue paper or printer paper between them. This goes behind the emblem. Update 08/10/16 -
Added links to some other emblem designs.
Modeled and uploaded a design for a back plate/base that will allow attachment of strip LED's. This is based on a mock-up I made from foam core that was used for the prototype.

Update 11/01/15 -
Added a back plate. It is about 1mm to wide but I enjoy sanding down and making for a snug fit. Eventually I'll go back and add some sort of screw of latch point.

This is a chest ring that was designed using a concept I had for making some cosplay props. Lots of superhero's and characters have design's a logo's located on their chest. title: iBox Nano Build Plate Holder and Carriage - REVISED

description.text: On the ibox Nano the carriage and build plate are made of acrylic. After a while these parts will start to crack. These are parts you can use to rebuild your carriage and build plate assemblies. You will be able to use all of the existing hardware. title: bed levelling calibration parametric concentric squares

description.text: This is a bed levelling helper, you can customise the bed size, line width and spacing using the scad file. As the lines are tightly packed it gives you more opportunities to make adjustments and see the result as it prints. You can also use it to asses how flat your print bed actually is over the entire surface. Using a bed levelling print seems to give better results than using a shim on its own (you should do that before attempting the print anyway).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Cura sometimes seems to have a problem printing walls with a thickness of double the nozzle size. Check the single layer view for layer 1 as it may be missing some parts of the print entirely. Slic3r seems to handle this better. You can adjust the line width and spacing using the scad file. You may also be able to get it to print in cura by temporarily adjusting your nozzle size although I'm not sure what other side effects this may have. The 150mm print object has 0.8mm line width and 1.2mm spacing. The 180mm print object has 1mm line width and 1mm spacing. Make sure your printer is centred correctly etc otherwise this could print off the edge.

author: plasticWrap

description.text: This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279. I just took the 19x19 base (16 holes) and cut it into quarters (using Netfabb Basic) so I could print on my printrbot SM. Added some holes/pegs (with 123D Design) so the pieces will fit together. Just print it four times, clean them up (may need to clean up the holes so the pegs will fit nice and snug). There's also some extra holes for a small screw in case they are too loose and need to be held together better. Note these screw holes are very small and were not made with any particular size/type in mind, so YMMV. My print (two pieces so far) doesn't look like screws will be needed. I'll add pics when I can. Edit: finally added some pics of the final assembled base. It did take some effort cleaning out the holes and pegs for a nice snug fit. I just used an Xacto knife to clean it up, then some pliers to gently force the pegs all the way in. I'm quite pleased with how it turned out.

description.text:
This creates a bowl shaped model where the interior shape is parabolic with a specific focal point exactly where the top of the microphone is defined. The parabola is configured so that the microphone points forward. This does create a much smaller bowl to pickup the sound, but I was able to build mine to a height of 250mm which made a decent size and worked well.
If you set the microphone height greater than the total height then you could make the parabola larger - but then you'll need to point the microphone backwards. Using a small cylinder shaped microphone that would insert to the exact length specified.
It will need to be adjusted for each microphone type. I used a splitter on my Android to separate the mic and headset and then used an hearing aid app to amplify the microphone input back into the headset. It worked pretty well. PS: I used it to listen to my family's heartbeat just by placing the cup on each of our chests. It was considerably louder than the stethoscope we have.

title: davinci replacement x axis idler pulley

description.text: UPDATE, use 683zz at 3x7x3mm to get enough material to make it strong enough. but really use a metal one with the appropriate dimensions. I found an issue with my da vinci x idler pulley squeaking, so I replaced the pulley with two 623ZZ (3x10x4mm) ball bearings and this printed part. You can also use 693ZZ (3x8x4mm) or MR63 (3x6x2.5) and make your own pulley. The issue is detailed here (http://voltivo.com/forum/davinci-hwmods/41-squeaking-and-or-circles-aren-t-round-check-this-56k-warn/reply/7767) and the solution is to replace the pulley with this part and ball bearings (and you may also have to replace the belt tensioner with something like thing:920971 or thing:921117 eventually). The actual OD for the bearings is 10mm, but I can't seem to get the pulley ID to print right, so I included a couple variations. Just add some tape if it's too loose, heat it up and press fit if it's too tight. You'll have to lightly hammer out the 3mm rod from the old pulley and into the new bearings since it's such a tight fit. You might also want to use some small m3 washers to prevent the tensioner from pinching this part and adding resistance. A final untested solution would be to use a premade pulley like this one (http://www.ebay.com/itm/3-x-16T-3mm-Bore-6mm-GT2-Belt-Smooth-Idler-Pulley-with-Bearing-for-3D-Printer-/131459526147?hash=item1e9b992e03:g:QL4AAOSwpDdU7Ybq) which has inset MR63 bearings (3mm ID, 6mm OD, 2.5mm thickness). I couldn't find a listing for less than 3 at a time, but it just so happens that I own 3 da vincis. Make sure to get a smooth one because GT2 is more popular and the these are actually S2M. A "16 tooth" sized pulley (no teeth, just the size of one with 16 teeth) is about the right size for the pulley (smaller so it fits, and not too wide. Again, you'll probably want washers.
