    -This thing allows me drawing lines and squares using the pen and the lcd with the rotary encoder (works as a jog dial) without starting a computer or loading any software. Let your children draw some artwork this way.
    -The plot area is ca. 160x130mm.
    -Some basic metal work required, cut of threads to holes on the bearings backside
    .
    If you are interisted but not sure if this is for you.
    I have linked some videos at the end of the text.
    They are showing what it is good for and how a plotter does his work.
    .
  • Please don't underestimate the effort you have to put in.
    It takes time.
    This is not plug and play.
    Know your machine.
    Tell it exactly to the point what and when to do.
    Read through until the end.
    You might take the benefit from what other poeple have gone through already.
    Are you disappointed now? Sorry, but thats not my fault.
    .
  • When you have finished the modification:
    -you might use the printer almost like a regular single pen plotter now.
    -please use evenly flat paper or pcb or whatever you are going to plot on. No relief on the paper please
    -operate the printer as a plotter contolled by software running on a USB-connected computer. Some essential hardware settings (software on your computer) need to be set. I do not cover changing the printers firmware for this purpose.
    .
    -Annotation:
    This machine is not SDcard slot operated only.
    We can operate this printer reliably from USB connected computers.
    It has NO essential differences with my other RepRap- and CNC-machines. Regarding the USB-howto read some hints included with the whole text.
    The workflow and the required machine settings differ from what we are using when printing filaments.
    Joke on:
    You have been warned, this is an understatement sort of.
    /Joke off:
    .
  • The springloaded penholder design
    -I have choosen Stabilo pens point No. 88 , because of its uniformly shaped shaft. This makes it much easier to achieve a perfect alignment of the guide holes and the clamp.
    -The moveable penholder block helps you to avoid puting to much pressure on the mechanics.
    -It can egalize some user errors (regarding to the configuration) and it helps surviving hard touch downs on the surface.
    -The springloaded penmount compensates some minor plot paper thickness variations.
    .
  • The printable parts:
    -mountplate
    -parts for Stabilo pen hexagonal shaped shaft, frame and clamping block
    If this does not match a pen you might have, please make a design of your own.
    Go creative.
    -x-travel limiter clamp (put the two parts together using 2 screws M3x25mm)
    (my remix of toolson P3steel x-endstop holder)
  • print out:
    -1x frame
    -1x pen clamping block
    -1x mountplate
    -1x x-travel limiter (if you are going to mount the pen rightside to avoid conflicts with the dragchain)
    .
    Otherwise you can make a mountplate fast from pcb , sheet of aluminium or similar. Make it has 3mm thickness, some standoffs required to bridge the gap with the screw holes start

• Read on the instructions until the hints section first.
  • Check if you have already printed all the required parts.

  • rise up the z-stop
    -the fastest way to achieve this:
    do some basic metal work
    Cut two tiny threaded screw holes at least 5mm obove the existing z-endstop.
    Put the switch to the metal frame there. Please screw it on, do NOT glue it on.
    -If metal working is not your style:
    print out something that rises the hight the z-endstop switch gets triggered.
    Look for some parts named adjustable z-endstop, z-riser, z-stop extension.
    Hint:
    Take my movable z-endstop solution.
    My solution ends fiddling with the bed screws for once and all.
    It has the z-stop clamped with a digital caliper slider.

  • Cutting of 2 threads M4 on each rod into the holes on the x-bearings back side required. Cut one each to the outermost left hole resp. right hole you find on the smooth rods .
    .
  • Required hardware:
    -soft metal spring ca. 15-20mm , the diameter should be a little wider than the diameter of the pen. You should be able to squeeze the spring with your fingers with ease.
    -2x screws M4 x 8mm (clamping block holds the pen)
    -2x screws M4 x 6mm (small heads, mounting the tube with the mountplate)
    -2x screws M4 x 16mm (mounting the mountplate with the x-bearings)
    .
    When you assemble the parts make the clamp has minimal possible friction when moving trough the channel in the tube. The pen should go easily through the holes (frame and block) but should not have noticeble play.
    .
  • usefull measurement tools:
    -Digital caliper attached:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1061915.
    -My gauge holder:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1109421
    -Other holders:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:926822
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:281338
    .
  • Having the pen plugged in requires some extra attention,
    -find the right z-hight,
    -limit the x-path using a clamp, put one next to the outermost left position on the smooth rods
    -don't exceed the limited plot area now
    -Think of it: your printer has NO endstops on the x-y-z-max position.
    -lift or remove the pen before you go to the next print (ink or filament as well)
    -Have an eye on the printer nozzle. Keep it high with a safety margin above the bed. This should be done by lifting the z-axis endstop.
    Nevertheless residues from filament may reach the bed.
    -Clean the nozzle before you start a plot.
    -This holder has no special z-follower functionality you may purchase for expansive prototyping machines or cnc routers cutting big uneven panels of plywood or steel.
    -The tip can NOT pass through holes, channels you have put there. It will break and block the drives.
    -LIFT the pen before it crosses those hollowed areas.
    .
  • setting up the z-hights (zero, homing, plot hight):
    For plotting the tip must get in contact with the paper, scratching it a little (very little only).
    Finding the perfect z-hight (esp. zero and plot) goes much easier having my digital caliper attached (alternatively use an old but trusty analog gauge or a micrometer).
    The first setup will be ok for regular paper now.
    Once set the applicable paper thickness range depends on the spring strength without further modification.
    Rule of thumb: the more strength the less the range.
    For strong springs and/or thicker material find an appropriate z-hight to start with.
    .
  • How to setup the z-axis zero (a little bit roughly the very first time)
    Check this:
    -You have done rising the z-axis enstop switch holder by i.e. 5mm (safety margin for the nozzle included )?
    -You have screwed the switchmount with the frame on the new position or clamped with the digital caliper slider (I have the z-endstop mounted on) with the setscrew? Checked again?
  • You have removed any SDcard from the printer slot. You have done this already, right?
    .
    -Connect your computer with the printer USB port.
    -In Repetier-Host connect the programm with the Melziboard.
    This may take a few seconds.
    -Switch over to the control "manual control" section.
    Now having connected the program with the Melziboard
    -hit the OK-button in the lower right area of the manual control tab window once.
    You will find the move control buttons in this window.
    -move the z-axis up (ca. 10-20mm above the top surface)
    .
    -Put the x-carriage in the middle of the second half of the bed.
    Remember, you have to put the z-axis in safe hight before you continue the procedure now.
    -Feed the pen (without the cap) through the holes, the block and the spring concurrently. Start from the top of the frame.
    The block should hold the pen. Otherwise secure the pen turning a screw fingertight.
  • Now the pen tip should NOT touch the bed/surface.
    Keep the pen tip a few millimeters above the bed (required for the moves on z-homing)
    -Perform the z-axis homing.
    -Loosen the screws.
    -Now, not earlier put the pen tip GENTLY toward the bed until it hits the surface. If nessecary fixate the pen with the screws loosely.
    -Repeat the homing.
    Continue with the fine adjustment now.
    .
  • z-Zero fine adjustment:
    -Do a z-home within the plot area (intentionally) no paper or whats ever.
    -Lift the z-axis by klicking the button in the manual control section window tab 1mm once. Adjust this gap hight accordingly to your needs later on.
    -Loosen the block screws now.
    -Check if the block went down to the frame bottom when you have lifted up the z-axis.
    -The tip must get/stay in touch with the surface while moving up the block, push it gently back down if nessecarry.
    -Tighten the block screws but don't break anything.
    -Check if you have the block moving freely.
    Move the block up a little, check if it holds the pen secured. Let the block go back.
    -Repeat the z-axis homing.
    Watch the pen tip.
    -The pen MUST go up apparently (relative move) easily together with the block when the z-axis drives reaches the z-zero hight until the switch gets triggered.
    This is very important.
    The little gap between the block and the frame has to be the same when you perform the next homing over the bed/surface without paper or pcb.
    .
  • Check your z-axis setup.
    -Rise the z-axis a few millimeters.
    -Put thin flat paper (ca. 0.1mm) on the bed loosely.
    -Home the z-axis in the middle of the plot area.
    -The paper should be moveable between the bed and the pen tip. If it scratches to much or can't move adjust the pen / lower the spring pressure.
    Do some artwork by moving the paper the pen writes on now.
    Have fun.
    Note:
    You might have found by accident one can plot onto the aluminium bed surface? It's Ok. Don't panic. The ink sticks very well but can be removed probably with spiritus or acetone from the bed later.
    .
  • Homing the z-axis:
    -You might consider moving the homing postion to the rear edge where the pen tip can go deeper than the bed/glass top surface.
    Some printers have a hole for those purposes and priming the nozzle.
    -You may define a park position for the pen with an elevated z-hight.
    .
  • How I do homing the z-axis with my setup:
    The tip can go down behind the rear edge of the bed without touching anything.
    Therefore the z-homing postion is X=0 Y=145. The regular homing position were X=0,Y=0. This has to be defined inside the gcode.
    I apply a homing sequenze:
    1. lift the z-axis to safe hight first (z=5mm)
    2. home the x,y-axis
    3. move to a safe position (X0,Y145)
    4. home the z-axis
    5. rise up the z-axis to a safe hight again (z=5mm)
      For sequenze details see the sample code below.
      .
  • When you are going to plot on thicker materials:
    -Home the z-axis in a safe area only.
    -take care on the plot z-hight
    -set the plot z-hight within the gcode
    -otherwise small changes can be done by adjusting the hight the pen tip touches the top surface (same with the fine adjustment, retract the pen by 1-3mm) without changing existing gcode.
    Attention: this lowers the safety margin with the nozzle.
    If this doesnt help you out:
    -change the mechanical setup with the z-stop mount
    -put the pen back to normal positon you have set earlier
    -rise up the z-endstop switch more
    -repeat the adjustments with the thick material on the bed this time
    .
  • The software:
    The big differences between printing filament and plotting/cutting:
    -the tool does it work at the stock top surface hight or lower.
    -A regular plotter doesn't need z-homing, infact regular desktop plotters don't have a z-axis assembly. The plot paper thickness may vary without an impact on the "z-axis".
    -A regular plotter does a "pen down" when drawing on the paper only.
    Regular plotter software would send a "pen down" command to a selonoid which pushes the pen downward the paper.
    -We have to move the whole z-axis down and up again instead.
  • It's up to you to manage lifting the pen allways. I can't stress this enough.
    -Don't use homing G28 for all axis concurrently while operating the pen on X0Y0.
    -Nevertheless G28 X0,Y0 can be performed as long as you have lifted the pen enough before.
  • When ever you can avoid scratching the naked bed/surface with the pen.
    .
    -How to make a testrun:
    Prepare your control software preferrable Repetier-Host.
    -Create a new machine profile. Give it a name i.e. "plotter".
    -Put the new cnc-style settings on your machine controller software.
    -Take a sheet of regular inkjet-printer paper size A4 or Legal, 80g/m2.
    -Cut it down to the size of your printbed. Attache it firmly and secure it.
    -Feed the machine with some gcode.
    Take the sample below.
    .
    Warning:
    Do you have any doubt? Don't let the pen touch down the first time.
    If you are fine with your machine put the pen to the working hight now.
    If you have done the fine adjustment and have checked your machine making some artwork - ignore this warning.
    .
  • Repetier-Host new cnc-style machine profile:
    -the dimensions:
    x-max=165mm
    Y-max=145mm
    -printable area:
    X print range =160mm
    Y print range=130mm
    Z=80mm
    .
    The sample code:
    This is for Wanhao Duplicator i3 (use it at your own risk):
    (Prusa i3 type, bed size 200x200mm,z-home at X0,Y145)
    -if nessecarily change the code manually
    -DON'T put the file you are going to make the next step directly on SDcard to the printer with unmodified firmware settings!!!
    -Paste the CODE below in an empty document give it a name test.gcode.
    -Load this file into Repetier-Host after you are done creating the new profile.
    .
    This short example performes homing subsequently and it plots a recangle.
    ; START
    ; Have you finished rising the z-axis endstop by 5mm?
    G21
    G90
    M106
    M18
    M01
    G1 Z5 F100
    G4 P2000
    G28 X0 Y0
    G4 P2000
    G1 X0 Y145 F4000.00
    G4 P2000
    G28 Z0 F50
    G4 P1000
    G1 Z5.0000 F100
    G4 P2000
    G1 X30.0000 Y30.0000 F4000.0000
    G1 Z0.5 F100
    G4 P3000
    G1 X30.0000 Y100.0000 F1000.0000
    G1 X100.0000 Y100.0000 F1000.0000
    G1 X100.0000 Y30.0000 F1000.0000
    G1 X30.0000 Y30.0000 F1000.0000
    G1 Z5 F100.00
    G4 P2000
    G0 X0 Y140 F3500.00
    M01
    M18
    ; THE END
    .
    Please take notice:
    I have found the printer working more reliably controlled from a computer via USB after I had removed the "autoreset"- jumper on the controller board.
    There is a known limit with the auxilary powersupply regarding the FTDI chip and the sd-slot controller.
    Avoid having a SDcard inserted when operating from USB.
    When you have running Repetier-Host on a Windoze PC:
    Disable all kinds of powersaving when running any plot/print-job.
    Hard to find but this is very important if not to say the most important entry:
    disable selective powersaving on the USB ports
    How to get it: got to ->system settings->power settings> find it hidden within the "change a power plan" or similar.
    Go through and open the "+"-tabs, look for "selective powersaving on the USB" ports-change the settings to 0=disabled
    .
    Got to the Windows device manager (hardware).
    Look for the internal USB-devices.
    Find the USB controllers.
    Expand their tabs.
    Look further for the (multiple) USB root hub devices.
    On each device deactivate the power saving option.
    .
    When you make your own code:
    IT TAKES TIME. Be patient.
  • You might get better command execution regarding the z-axis:
    acivate the Ping-Pong-command option within the machine settings profile.
    This promisses to wait for the OK comming from the Melziboard after a command has been sended before sending the next command.
  • Put some pause commands between the commands one following the other that move the heavy mechanical parts.
    -You may have to rearrange the commands order.
    .
    I have found this crucial fact (I have not had with my other printer and the cnc as well):
    -When the pause and z-lift command is written the same line the lift / pause commands might be SCIPPED/IGNORED when executing the file.
    -It takes time: pause at least 0.5-1 sec when you have commanded a z-axis move (short distances) . Any controller has no idea where the z-axis really is ( the only one exception: homing the z-axis, when you hit the endstop switch).
    -Put each the lift and pause commands in separate command lines sepatated from the xy movements.
    -Take care with your design when you plot something afterwards i.e. onto already drilled pcb.
    -As seen with the sample above, rectify the code programs have created.
    -Remove unwanted code fragments.
    -The pen has to be downed /lifted at the starting/end point of a line.
    Many programs (as cad.py does) put the move to the next postion and z-hight commands in one line ignoring the spezial features of our fake plotter.
    -Lift up the z-axis first, wait,move to the desired positon then, lift down the z-axis, wait , plot the line segment then and vice versa.
    The more you know your printer the less you can set the wait cycles with confidence.
    -Remove comments or put a ";" before
    -Plot speed depends on paper, your pens ink flow rate and the drying time.
    -Don't go to low with the speed and low to much with z-hight.This will put to much ink on the paper. The plot would blur out and/or the tip will scratch the paper to much.
    .

  • Read these guides:
    -convert pictures to plotable gcode:
    http://www.instructables.com/id/Pocket-laser-engraver/step7/Getting-the-software-ready/ (this is for vector graphics you may draw using Inkscape)
    -https://docs.google.com/document/d/1B3X64yJnW0h7DfCIhDnKzGpdfE9PtDYOhGhyjhRFcOs/edit?usp=sharing
    -make pcb on Modela CNC machine using cad.py
    http://makeyourbot.wikidot.com/cad-py
    .

  • Future application:
    The mountplate has room for future extension(s). To be mounted on the second half of the plate.
    -mini pcb drill motor mount
    -Attach a laser diode or a z-auto- hight probe here.
    -Use it with a selenoid working as an actuator.
    This would leave the z-switch untouched. The selenoid could push the pen downward against the bottom mounted spring then. Some folks have build this already so I do not have to invent this again. But nevertheless some wiring with the selenoid is required then. With no additional outputs on the Melziboard the filament cooler fan has to be exchanged with the selenoid. With the gcode you have to swap actuator commands (pen-up, pen-down) with the fan related commands (0%, 100%). If it dares you ask Google for it.
    .
  • Watch some some nice videos on DIY plotters
    .
    -Sasan printer working as a plotter (pen fixed mounted)
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G9-Dh2GcvBs
    .
    -unfinished printer working as a plotter (pen glued on)
    youtube.com/watch?v=B3ov7AOVwbU
    .
    -printer has the extruder replaced with the pen fixed mounted
    youtube.com/watch?v=DtufqB3d6L0
    .
    -Dirk's Robin PCB printer THIS is the one I like most ;-)
    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m68qDGWKY_U
    .
    -RadaR pen plotter
    Nice build made from metal construction kit for kids and a few printed bearing holders (shows the plotter working at 1:37min)
    youtube.com/watch?v=aivK2X7fA9U&index=4
    .
    -Nitesh diy plotter (shows the plotter working at 0:30min)
    youtube.com/watch?v=3P3o2M6ijh0
    .
  • videos on lifting down and up the pen using a selenoid or rc-model-servo
    -Kattejiuce xy plotter
    youtube.com/watch?v=cEko5fpgAnk
    -Sasan xy plotter
    a string driven xy pen plotter using cad.py to generate gcode
    youtube.com/watch?v=vhRJGyLVwS4
    -James Sesler tilting pen mount
    youtube.com/watch?v=hNzGgxicLzE
    .
  • videos on making your own pcb using a 3d printer equipped with a pen:
    youtube.com/watch?v=w_SC7YzHa-8
    youtube.com/watch?v=Sum2vJyR8RM
    youtube.com/watch?v=tziwG9Ur_8A
    .
  • examples for small future extensions:
    -watch on youtube kkAE-Br1Wok, this mod makes the printer a calligraphic writing machine ;-)
    .
    -make pcb using a laser and photoresist
    youtube.com/watch?v=z-LwZUMyuXE
    .
  • Testplot: file test_bed_level.gcode
    -This let you draw lines across the whole plotarea.
    -It let you check if the bed surface is evenly flat.
    How to:
    -Adjust the x-axis level against the ground first,
    -adjust the bed level using the 4 screws.
    -Put a sheet of paper sized 200x200mm on the bed.
    -Lift the z-axis to 0.5mm.
    -Adjust the pen tip can barely touch the paper.
    -Disengage the motors.
    -Move the carrier by hand or using the controler panel and the knob for fast x-y-positioning.
    -Check if the pen tip reaches the paper when you move to the 4 corners subsequently.
    -If all set start the plot.
    .
  • If you have another pen up to 10mm diameter maximal:
    -How to put bigger holes in the frame and the block:
    1. software method:
      -load the stl-files in Tinkercad an put bigger holes in
      align all holes centered (coaxial).
      Probably you have to fine tune the holes using a sanding cylinder tool I have described below.
      .
    2. physical method:
      -Print the files with increased infill it makes it almost a solid part.
      This makes it more robust so it wan't break easely when you rework it with hardware tools.
      -Make the holes bigger matching your pen size.
      Take a drill at very low speed and cut the holes applying very little pressure only.
      Turn it by hand preferrably and/or sanding paper.
      Wind the sanding paper around a slightly smaller bolt/pen/pipe.
      This gives you a sanding cylinder tool.
      .
      Keep the tolerances tight. No wiggle please!
      Bring the holes diameter exactly to the pens outer diameter.
      It makes no sense feeding a thin pen through a wide hole.
      Don't do it. It wan't give you good drawings.

In the image, I used 8mm color stickers for the ends of the pawns to help differentiate them from one another.

description.text: I decided to make some accessories for my Robo 3D hole cover (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:990408). I've been working with Bamhm182 on the Robo 3D Community forum and here with an alternative to mounting the cable chain link end to the side of the printer with screws or adhesive. We both have two different directions we are going with our chain link routing, but having the link end incorporated into the hole cover was a common idea. Thank you Bamhm182 for your help with this. I ended up designing a modular plug to go into the end of the cover. Goals in this design were to make it universal, tool free, and easy as possible to install or remove from the cover as well as the deck of the printer. You can find a blank version so you can add your own ideas to it. I have included a version with a slightly smaller hole that adds the lip needed to secure the cover to the deck lip underneath if you want. Original design stays in place just fine though. I have also included two versions of the chain link end as follows. V1 (pictured above) will work great with SonnyDr's latest version of the chain links and the motor mount cover found here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1091510). He made the cover pretty slick and moved the starter link forward and pointing to the left to make the chain movement more compact and inline with the front of the printer. The best part is he added a new link design that makes it so you don't have to remove the wiring. Very cool. So V1 will make a good termination point to the chain that clips to the hole cover and the deck of the printer (so it won't pull up during operation). You also won't need to mess with it when wanting to remove the printer cover anymore. V2 is a version I made for a slight variant to the original chain link design for the Robo 3D that InAppDesign posted here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:696183). I'll update this with the completed assembly remix once I have had a chance to print everything out. Reprinting my links with SonnyDR's versions now. Stay tuned for that project. Not a huge change to the cover, but I hope it helps a couple folks out there with their mod projects and ideas with the Robo 3D. Great printer for the money and allows a lot of creativity for modifications if desired. Please let me know what you think of these accessories in the comments. If you make one, please include a pic or two in the "I Made One" section. Happy printing!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm (200 microns)

Infill:

I used 100% since no thick areas

Notes: Pay attention to the model orientation when printing. You might find rotating the part on its side will keep the amount of support needed down a bit. Sorry about the need for support. I don't like modeling things this way, but it was necessary for this part for the sliding channels. I used Cura with "support everywhere" enabled for the inner channel. Supports removed easily and just took a file quick to the inside surfaces to clean it up.

comments.text: So sorry Pergo. I missed this comment. Christmas has been crazy for me. So if you don't want to use the mount used for the extruder stepper motor, then the other option is to use the alternate model that starts the wiring on the back of the x carriage. At home I have a model that allows you to just print and screw onto the x carriage for that starting mount. Otherwise, there is a model on here that requires a full reprint of the x carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:696183). Using this as a starting point will bring your wiring in a different orientation than the one Herby put together in 1154650. I designed the V1 chain end for his design since the chain comes over in front of the z axis. V2 is for a project I haven't finished to have the chain come over in back of the z axis into an adapter I designed that bolts onto the x stepper motor bracket (not the motor itself) and continues the chain back to the hole cover plate. I'm sorry I haven't beta tested that design yet to make it public. 1154650 has a great design for the links so you can easily adapt the chain to the wiring without removing the wiring. I would use that or something similar for sure. How many links you will ultimately need, I don't know yet. If you don't want to cover the stepper motor because of heat, than I would suggest using the back starting point design. Unfortunately, at the moment that will require you to attach to the ROBO lid and makes it difficult when removing the lid. After Christmas is over, I promise to finish my design that will make it so you don't attach to the lid. Sorry about that. I can load the file tonight for just the part needed to screw onto the back left of the x carriage to get you started if you don't want to print a whole new x carriage. I'll just flag it as a work in progress.

author: 3dmaster

description.text:
I saw this hanging drain thing in The Wolverine and wanted to make it.
You hang it outside and when it rains the water collects and flows from cup to cup. The cups have a little notch in them. Print the holders and slot them into the notches of the cup then pass some wire through the hole in the holders to chain.
Wait that's not enough. D: You need to tie knots so that the holders are held in place. I forgot about that. Maybe I'll redesign how that works later

Add some jingle to your drumming. This is sized to fit on Vater Fusion model sticks but they should fit anything with a 14.5mm diameter. Each pin compresses to slide on two tambourine jingles and then you can open the pin up to keep the jingles on.
This isn't a permanent percussive accessory due to the plastic pins not being excessively strong but I played with them for a few hours with no problems. If you're a hard hitter your results may vary. Video of the design and print here: https://youtu.be/z7EKJOaeJP0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

The pins are obviously the weak point on this. The hex cutout is also designed that way to hopefully grip the stick better than just a circle. Heavy playing or hitting rim will probably result in breaking. I also noticed the stick would start to slip if you put on and take off repeatedly. Some tape above and below the print solved that problem. I also ended up slightly spreading the pins out at the top and adding a drop of hot glue to prevent the jingles from popping off.

description.text:
This device was designed for the assistive tech challenge.
The EzyOpen is a basic, strong and simple wrench style opener for people that suffer from sore joints, or arthritis, which can make opening tight lids very irritating. The ergonomic design allows for an easy and strong grip on things like small jars, pill containers, bottles and many other common household containers. The springy head also allows fitment over many different size lids.
The teeth around the inside of the EzyOpen allow for a strong grip on tight lids, while the comfortable handle gives maximum leverage and control, all with minimal effort. The compact size of the EzyOpen also allows for fast, hassle free 3D printing and easy storage.
With a simple squeeze and twist action, any lid can be loosened with ease :)

description.text: I was looking for a modular, printable filament spool that required minimal hardware to assemble. description.text:
The devices was produced to assist people with limited hand grip capability. After many trials and error the best solution to the problem was an artist egg. Styrofoam egg that cost about 50cents.
The problem however is that the utensil pushes through the end of the egg (pictured). This plug solves this problem and creates a very inexpensive grip. This grip was preferred over the OT foam tube that was given to the patient in hospital. Print the plug and screw it into the egg... Look at photos for instructions
